channel.title: Ezra Citrons Website
channel.description: Recent content on Ezra Citrons Website

item.title: Upgrade Your Visuals
item.description: This will be a three part series, the first will describe high, level how one can go about upgrading their vis skills, some resources, and packages that we can use. We’ll run through an example in a subsequent post. The post is heavily inspired by the work of Cedric Scherer (I thought i was pretty good before i saw this guy) and posts from The Pudding Good, like really good visulisation library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.

item.title: Be smart with file manipulation
item.description: Classic problem I stumbled across recently. I had a bunch of files in a directory, and i wanted to rename them all at once. Perfect excuse, i thought to myself, to check out the fs (in R) package for manipulating files. What is a file what is a directory Good to be clear at the offset. A directory is where you store your files. They call it a tree structure, because it looks like a tree.

item.title: Consider blogging
item.description: :boom: I think good data scientist should consider blogging Lets cut to the chase here, in no particular order these are the skills that blogging will help you with. ordering your thoughts reminding yourself of things you’ve forgotten you knew how to do finishing things. Communicating results to a non-technical audience. practicing reproducibilty -incentive to stay curious. I’m more likely to go that extra mile to check out an interesting sounding package if i think it could be the makings of an interesting blog post.

item.title: Eminem Lyric analysis with R
item.description: Text Mining with Eminem Text mining promises a lot. The ability to get a machine to understand the main topics in a text, or how positive the writer was about the subject could have applications as far reaching as law, analysing survey responces, stock market analysis. I usually favor simplicity over perfection. I’d rather have a 6/10 model that I can interpret and (crucially) explain than a 9/10 model that no one can get their head around.

item.title: How to not reinvent the wheel
item.description: Machine learning is a large topic, but if you are ever at the cross roads and the choice is between picking an unfamiliar novel technique and an old classic. Be very sure that there is tangable advantage to going with the more complex solution. There is a takeoff between predictive power and interpretablilty. Sometime i feel like this graph should be stapled to my forehead. Learning Curb Modeling does not work in silos, there is significant time cost involved with getting everyone up to speed.

item.title: Purrr, the most underrated package in the tidyverse
item.description: Map Reduce Possibly, Safely, Quieitly Possibly (along with similar function safelyt and quitely) are all functions which update the behaviour or other functions, so that if (read: when) something goes wrong in your code, R doesnt have a strop, and halt your code, loosing all your progress, you can decide its behavior. Here, i will tell R that if i dont get the lyrics, song dataframe i want, just retrun an empty one and add it to the list.

item.title: Stop thinking, start simulating
item.description: My mother is a keen reader of ‘the daily scientist’, a UK based popular science magazine. Invariably over a given weekend she’ll exclaim that the latest estimate for the age universe or . Unusually, she shared a piece that I got me interested, so here it is… "Dog breeder Harriet Hound’s prize pooch has just had 10 puppies. She is particularly pleased, because there are only nine puppies in the latest litter of her arch-rival, Matilda Mutt.

item.title: Understanding what is possible over remembering how to do it
Will the real scrapy please stand up
item.description: Scraping lyrics Title puns aside, I’ll be using the rvest package to scrape all Eminem song lyrics from here We will also need to clean up these columns using regex Now that we have our function to get the lyrics extract_lyrics_from_link and parse_lyrics to clean it up, we can simply loop over the number of songs on the website, and save all the lyrics. Ahh, the satisfaction of running a loop…

item.title: About Me
item.description: Hi, welcome to my blog! I’m a maths graduate now working as a data scientist in the city of London. I’ll be using this blog to write up topics that i find interesting, or just code that I find elegant and occasionally just general musings. Feel free to leave a comment beneath my posts a get involved. About my blog This blog is just as much for me as for you.

item.title: Resources
item.description: Here is a collection of things that i use. I hope to update this regularly R and packages R for Data Science for me is the definitive guide to Data Science in R. It is both highly approachable and can really get you quite far along with your data needs. The resource for building package in R.R Packages by Hadley Wickham. tidytext for interpretable ways of gaining insight from text data
